item.title: Rick Caruso Will Not Run for L.A. Mayor or California Governor in 2026
item.description: Mr. Caruso had the potential to shake up the contests for Los Angeles mayor or California governor.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rick Caruso, who lost his 2022 race for Los Angeles mayor, was considered a potential heavyweight as a candidate in 2026.

item.title: Court Blocks Trump Administration From Freezing Food Stamps in Minnesota
item.description: With tensions high between the White House and the state, the ruling temporarily halted plans to withhold over $129 million in funding.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A food pantry in Detroit Lakes, Minn., last year.

item.title: Judge Restricts Immigration Agents’ Actions Toward Minnesota Protesters
item.description: A federal judge ordered agents not to retaliate against people “engaging in peaceful and unobstructive protest activity” in the state and not to stop drivers who are not “forcibly obstructing” officers.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Minnesota residents have clashed with federal agents since late 2025, when the federal government began an immigration enforcement campaign that it named Operation Metro Surge.

item.title: Trump Administration Begins Criminal Inquiry Into Minnesota Leaders
item.description: The Justice Department’s investigation is a major escalation in the state-federal battle over the conduct of immigration agents in Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Alan Feuer, Devlin Barrett and Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Ryan Murphy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jacob Frey, the mayor of Minneapolis, at a news conference this month. He and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota are being investigated by the Justice Department, according to a senior law enforcement official.

item.title: Trump Announces Members for Gaza ‘Board of Peace,’ Including Rubio and Kushner
item.description: The president also tapped a U.S. general to lead an international peacekeeping force that will be deployed to disarm Hamas and occupy Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gaza City on Tuesday. Most of Gaza has been destroyed by Israeli bombardment over more than two years of war.

item.title: AI Attack Ad in Texas Senate Race Shows John Cornyn Dancing With Jasmine Crockett
item.description: A video from Ken Paxton, a Republican primary challenger to Senator John Cornyn of Texas, depicted A.I.-generated imagery of the senator twirling with Jasmine Crockett, a Democratic Senate candidate.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general, is challenging Senator John Cornyn, a fellow Republican.

item.title: How ICE Tensions and Immigration Politics Could Shape 2026 Midterm Elections
item.description: Three reporters discuss the Minneapolis chaos and how it could play a role in the midterms.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis.

item.title: Trump Has Machado’s Nobel Prize, but Neither Got What They Really Wanted
item.description: President Trump has María Corina Machado’s medal, but he is not recognized as the prize laureate. Ms. Machado did not win Mr. Trump’s endorsement to become Venezuela’s president.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado’s decision to present her Nobel Peace Prize medal to President Trump has been met with mixed reviews in the United States and abroad.

item.title: F.A.A. Urges ‘Caution’ Over Oceans in Latin America, Warning of Military Activity
item.description: The Federal Aviation Administration released seven advisories warning pilots to stay away from parts of the Pacific Ocean near Mexico, Colombia, Ecuador and Panama.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An American F-35 fighter jet taking off from an airport in Puerto Rico in December.

item.title: Man Who Attacked ‘Grandpa Vicha’ in San Francisco Is Found Not Guilty of Murder
item.description: Instead, the man was convicted of lesser charges, including involuntary manslaughter, in the death of Vicha Ratanapakdee. The killing became a symbol of rising attacks against Asians during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Monthanus Ratanapakdee with a picture of her father, Vicha Ratanapakdee, in 2021. Mr. Ratanapakdee was shoved to the ground while out on a walk in San Francisco that year, and died from his injuries.

item.title: U.S. Boardings of Oil Tankers Reflect Hard Lessons Learned at Sea
item.description: Videos show U.S. forces descending quickly from helicopters onto the tankers, two years after a tragic boarding attempt.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Russell Cheyne/Reuters
item.media:description: The oil tanker Marinera, previously known as Bella 1, was seized by the U.S. Coast Guard and seen off the coast of Scotland this week.

item.title: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to Warrants for Phone Location Data
item.description: The case involves a challenge to so-called geofence warrants, which permit law enforcement officials to sweep up location data of people near crime scenes.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle
item.media:credit: Steve Helber/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Call Federal Credit Union in Midlothian, Va., in 2020. The legality of a warrant for cellular phone data from an area around the bank is at question.

item.title: Judge Recommends U.S. Issue Visa to Student Who Was Deported in Error
item.description: A federal prosecutor apologized this week, saying an ICE officer made a “mistake” in deporting Any Lucia López Belloza, a college freshman in Massachusetts, to Honduras.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Any Lucia Lopez Belloza's attorney, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Any Lucia López Belloza celebrating her high school graduation in Texas last year. She was attending college in Massachusetts before her deportation in November.

item.title: Some U.Va. Board Members Asked to Resign as Gov. Abigail Spanberger Takes Power
item.description: After months of upheaval at the state’s flagship university, a new Democratic governor appeared ready to shake up the school’s leadership.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt and Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Saul Loeb/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Virginia’s governor-elect, Abigail Spanberger, will be sworn in on Saturday.

item.title: ICE vs. Ice: Protesters in Minneapolis Find an Ally in Winter
item.description: Temperatures are expected to plunge to around zero degrees this weekend. Minnesotans say they will be out in the street, using the weather to their advantage.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents contend with icy sidewalks as they try to contain protests in a Minneapolis January.

item.title: Trump Appoints Allies to Review His Ballroom Plans
item.description: A federal judge has allowed the ballroom project to proceed after the Trump administration pledged to undergo a review by the Commission of Fine Arts.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: A model of the proposed White House ballroom on President Trump’s desk in the Oval Office last month.

item.title: Leadership Dispute Said to Spur Abrupt Exit at the National Constitution Center
item.description: The congressionally chartered museum and national town hall has not explained the sudden departure of Jeffrey Rosen as its president and chief executive.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Jim Lo Scalzo/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The National Constitution Center in Philadelphia embodies the civil center of the legal establishment.

item.title: Will the ICE Agent Who Shot Renee Good Be Prosecuted?
item.description: With the Trump administration unlikely to bring a federal case against the ICE agent who killed Renee Good, our criminal justice reporter Jonah Bromwich explains some of the obstacles for any Minnesota prosecutors trying to charge the agent.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich, Christina Shaman, Nikolay Nikolov, June Kim and Sutton Raphael

item.title: Mexico’s president defends her nation’s antidrug efforts following U.S. criticism.
item.dc:creator: David Shortell
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mexican Army soldiers in Culiacán, Mexico, in October. President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico said efforts within Mexico had helped cut U.S. seizures of fentanyl at the border by half.

item.title: Trump Sets Fraudster Free From Prison for a Second Time
item.description: The president issued a raft of clemency grants this week, including pardoning a woman he had given relief to once before and a man whose daughter had donated millions to a Trump super PAC.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel and Susanne Craig
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: The pardons from President Trump continue a trend in which he has used the unfettered presidential clemency power to reward allies and those who have paid his associates or donated to his political operation.

item.title: Trump Backs Down on Insurrection Act as Democrats Take the Offensive
item.description: Officials denounced the Trump immigration crackdown in Minneapolis at an unofficial congressional hearing, while the president said he no longer saw a need to send in military forces.
item.dc:creator: Jazmine Ulloa
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Three congressional representatives from Minnesota tried to inspect immigration facilities at a federal building in Minneapolis last week. From left, Kelly Morrison, Ilhan Omar and Angie Craig were turned away after briefly being allowed inside.

item.title: Trump Praises Hassett, but Casts Doubt on Making Him Fed Chair
item.description: The blowback set off by the Justice Department’s criminal investigation into Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the central bank, has shaken up the race to replace him.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith and Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Kevin A. Hassett serves as the director of the White House National Economic Council.

item.title: U.S. Lawmakers Meet With Danish Prime Minister on Greenland
item.description: Seeking to calm tensions, Republicans and Democrats affirmed that they supported Denmark’s control of Greenland as President Trump vowed to buy it or take it over.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Bumiller and Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Chris Coons, Democrat of Delaware, led a delegation of American lawmakers on a visit to Denmark on Friday.

item.title: Why Is It So Hard to Set a 9/11 Trial Date? Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Prosecutors want jury selection to start in January 2027. That would be a quarter century after the attacks that killed nearly 3,000 people.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: James Hagan, a volunteer firefighter who lost his sister on Sept. 11, 2001, looking at the World Trade Center memorial in Manhattan last year.

item.title: Powell, an Unlikely Foil, Takes On Trump
item.description: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, this week tapped a groundswell of support that has been years in the making.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: The overwhelming defense of Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, is the product of something President Trump may have underestimated: Mr. Powell’s popularity.

item.title: Agent Who Shot Renee Good in Minneapolis Was Trained to Track and Apprehend Fugitives
item.description: From Iraq to ICE, Jonathan Ross’s career reflects a 20-year government effort to reshape immigration enforcement with a military mind-set.
item.dc:creator: Katie J.M. Baker

item.title: Trump Store to Close as Sales Falter, With No Election Battles Ahead
item.description: The shop in suburban Philadelphia had been a gathering spot for the MAGA crowd to rally during the 2024 campaign.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mike Domanico, the owner of a store that sells Trump merchandise in Bensalem, Pa., said it was time to close its doors.

item.title: C.I.A. Director Meets With Venezuela’s Interim President in Caracas
item.description: The high-profile visit, which could be seen as snubbing the opposition, comes nearly two weeks after the U.S. military seized President Nicolás Maduro in a raid.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: John Ratcliffe, the C.I.A. director, at the U.S. Capitol last week. On Thursday, he met with Delcy Rodríguez, the interim president of Venezuela, and delivered a message of cooperation.

item.title: Virginia Moves Closer to New House Maps That Could Set Democrats Up for a Win
item.description: Voters will now get a say over whether the current maps can be redrawn ahead of the 2026 midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson
item.media:credit: Steve Helber/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Virginia State Capitol in Richmond, Va.

item.title: Renee Good Was Concerned About ICE, a Lawyer Says, but Wasn’t Following Agents
item.description: A lawyer for Ms. Good’s family said she and her partner had encountered agents after school drop-off. Minutes later, she was dead.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for Renee Good near where she was fatally shot in Minneapolis.

item.title: What Happened to London Breed, the Former San Francisco Mayor?
item.description: London Breed has said little in the year since she left office. She has thoughts on the praise that the current mayor, Daniel Lurie, has received.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight
item.media:credit: Bethany Mollenkof for The New York Times
item.media:description: London Breed, the former mayor of San Francisco, is still adjusting to life beyond City Hall a year after she left office.
